analytic.title: Inks Used to Write the Divine Name in a Thirteenth-Century Ashkenazic Torah Scroll: Erfurt 7 (Staatsbibliothek zu Berlin, Ms. or. fol. 1216)

biblStruct.note: The scribe of ‘Erfurt 7’, a thirteenth-century Torah scroll now kept in Berlin, initially left blank spaces for the divine appellations Elohim (אלהים) and YHWH Elohim (יהוה אלהים) which were filled in during a second stage of writing. The appearance

body.bibl: Gordon, Nehemia, Olivier Bonnerot, and Ira Rabin. “Inks Used to Write the Divine Name in a Thirteenth-Century Ashkenazic Torah Scroll: Erfurt 7 (Staatsbibliothek Zu Berlin, Ms. or. Fol. 1216).” Manuscript Cultures 15 (2020): 163–84.

Nehemia Gordon, Olivier Bonnerot, and Ira Rabin, Inks Used to Write the Divine Name in a Thirteenth-Century Ashkenazic Torah Scroll: Erfurt 7 (Staatsbibliothek Zu Berlin, Ms. or. Fol. 1216), Manuscript Cultures 15 (2020): 163–84.
